Reviews.Title: Wow, breath-taking shots.
Reviews.Author: TheAbbey
Reviews.Content: Got this piece some months ago and didn't review so I can write something trustworthy.This camera is simply amazing. with its 50x optical zoom which I prefer to describe more as 24mm - 1200mm so anyone can feel it like I do. I also call it a spyware. Its just amazing. The Video is impressive though wish the AF is faster but for the price, its more than the bargain.So, if you're contemplating, you've got nothing to fear save what you're missing not owning one.wished canon begin to build the auto stitch panoramic shot

Reviews.Title: Canon SX-50 Powershot Camera
Reviews.Author: Chuck
Reviews.Content: Right out of the box, it took perfectly great pictures, this a camera that I will use for a long time.

Reviews.Title: Very nice camera.
Reviews.Author: Thomas Herfel
Reviews.Content: I was familiar with the camera before I ordered it.  I had checked it out at a local store and also watched several reviews on You Tube.  Also, a friend of mine has one.  So I knew what I was getting.  I wanted an easy to use camera with a (relatively) high-power telephoto lens primarily for wildlife photography.  This camera has that, but also does HD video and has a really neat macro function.  Not being a teenager, or a camera buff, and only having had the camera for a few weeks, I'm still learning.  But most functions seem relatively straight forward.  I also purchased a couple 16 GB cards, but these hold a huge number of pictures and you may not require one that large.  The rechargeable battery is easy in/out and recharges (usually) in an hour or so.  I've not had other cameras like this, other than a Canon SLR film camera several years ago, so I really can't compare it with other brands or similar devices.  But at this point I have no con's to report regarding the camera.

Reviews.Title: Super zoom
Reviews.Author: RGA
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera! It has all the convenience of a point-and-shoot, but also has a great deal of the sophistication you would fine in a DSLR. No need to swap lenses as this is ridiculously powerful. Planning to get an external flash unit (it has a built in and a hot-shoe), but have not needed it yet, as the built in is pretty good. So far, this does it all.

Reviews.Title: exceptional camera
Reviews.Author: James
Reviews.Content: I take a lot of bird pictures and sit beside a table on my sunroom with the camera mounted on a table tripod.  With the zoom I shoot birds at 4 different feeders at different distances  The picture s are clear and sharp. at all distances.  IVe also walked around the yard and taken amazing flower pictures. For the price this is an amazing camera.

Reviews.Title: The Perfect Camera--a point and shoot with so much more funcionality!
Reviews.Author: L. Proud
Reviews.Content: I wanted a high quality, fairly easy to use camera (I didn't want to have to re-learn all the DSLR stuff) with a killer telephoto lens so I can photograph the eagle family in the preserve across the canal from my lanai.  I got all that and more in this Canon.  After playing with it for a week, I took it to a family wedding to try to get a few pics that the mother of the groom asked me to get.  It proved to be lightweight enough to carry around, sharp enough to take really nice closeups from a distance, and the burst is fantastic.  But above all, I was able to stand about 15 feet away from my nephew as he played guitar and sang a song--without any shake or fuzziness--just beautiful video with great sound!  I was able to get the entire 4+ minute song without messing any of it up!I have since transferred almost 1000 photos from the camera to my laptop with no issues and am in the process of editing them.  I'm very happy with all aspects of this camera!

Reviews.Title: Great bridge camera!
Reviews.Author: Candice Boothe
Reviews.Content: My husband and I were in the market for a new camera as what we would be replacing had lower megapixels than our cameras on our phones. It was time for an upgrade! After extensive research online and recommendations from friends we decided to go with the SX50. We wanted something that had the ability to be customized as I learned more about photography and would be similar to a DSLR yet we also wanted to be able to just "point and shoot" until I got the hang of it all. I enjoy taking photos but I really have no idea what a lot of the terminology is yet. The idea of getting a DSLR was really intimidating, plus the cost difference was pretty substantial if we were going to go with the "best" beginner DSLR out there. The SX50 offered the chance for me to learn more while still have an automatic setting that could take all the guess work out of it for me. Less than a week after we got the camera we went to a friend's wedding. The 4 hour plane ride to get there allowed me some time to play around with all the settings and trying to learn some tricks to get good pictures at the wedding. At the wedding though, I wasn't comfortable enough to actually use any of the settings so I took nearly all of the photos on the auto setting. It actually worked out ok because the auto setting took GREAT pics! Since we've been home I've gotten the chance to mess around with the settings a little bit more and I'm slowly starting to get more comfortable with them and what they do. I'm really happy that I'm able to do that. Other features about the camera that we really like are the 50x zoom. I had no idea how far that really is until I was taking pictures from my couch of a squirrel outside in a tree-I got so close that it looked like he was sitting right next to me! We also really like the screen and the way it can be folding back to protect it. Another camera we were thinking of getting was the Nikon P510 but we really disliked how the screen on that one moved. With the Canon we can put the screen facing in to protect it from being damaged when we aren't using it and that is a huge plus-the last thing I want to worry about is breaking the screen because we couldn't protect it.Overall, we really like this camera and are really happy we got it. We've yet to do a lot of picture taking since Spring has taken a while to show up and we haven't been outdoors a lot yet. But once we're able to I plan to have that camera by my side taking all kinds of different pictures!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Loy R Knight
Reviews.Content: Wonderful choice for a point and shoot with outstanding optical zoom.  Exactly what I was looking for.  Pictures great and very easy to use for most pictures.

Reviews.Title: From Point & Shoot perspective
Reviews.Author: C. G. King
Reviews.Content: There are good reviews here from knowledgeable photographers. Mine's from the simpler view of what this camera is like for a Point & Shooter.  I can't even call myself an amateur photographer and know nothing about ISO and such. I wanted a camera with a great zoom that would take quality pictures, but that was pretty simple and fast since my subjects are likely not going to sit still while I fiddle with controls.  My father loved photography and developed his own pictures back in the day, but he was never able to teach my mother the fine points so I spent half my childhood posing for lengthy sessions while she struggled with f stops, focus and lighting.  My grandchildren are used to quick camera phones and aren't going to be sitting still for me doing the same.  My camera has to be fast, smart, easy and reliable.Since I live in the country I especially enjoy nature photography, but the wild turkeys refuse to come close enough for me to get decent pictures of them, the little birds seldom pose for long and the deer and other creatures are pretty jittery subjects.  I needed a really good zoom, auto focus, multiple shots with one press of the button sometimes, an easy way to go from movies to still shots and a fast way to access different functions.  This camera does the best job of the three I've tried and I like it, but there are a couple of issues too.It does not come with a cable to plug it into your computer.  If you have a newer computer you may have slots to insert the camera's SD card instead of plugging the camera into a USB port to remove the pictures, BUT if you want the software and user guide installed, you have to plug in the camera.  Hummm.  Luckily I have a smaller PowerShot camera and already had a cable with a mini connector that would work (there's also a slot for a wider flater connector), but I'd have been pretty annoyed if I didn't.  The second downside for me is that I'd really like to try the software, but can't get it.  The software is not on the CD like I expected.  The CD just starts the installation process and determines what model camera this is.  It then downloads the software from the internet (without telling you that's what it's going to do).  This may not be a problem for some users, but for those of us out in the sticks with poor internet access and maybe a data limit to boot, this is a huge problem.  After two tries and nearly 1 GB of data (which pushed me so close to my limit I can't do much of anything further till my cycle rolls over), I was able to get only the Image Browser which is not for extracting the pictures from the camera, but for organizing the pictures in your MyPictures folder.  I totally don't care about that and can't believe I wasted 1 GB  and two hours to get it.  Nothing tells you what the various software components are or how big the files are.Windows is happy to download my pictures and videos just like it does with my phone, but since I was unable to get the other items listed in the software download, I don't know what I may be missing.  I manually searched the CD and found the pdf file for the User Guide in the folder 'ReadMe', subfolder 'en' for English. Once you've started the 'easy' installation process for the software, you can't choose just to install the user guide, so I don't know how else you're going to get it but this manual method. I recommend choosing the 'custom' installation where I assume you could choose to get the User Guide installed first and then later decide if you want the other components.  The installation screen tells you almost nothing useful. Very dumb--and in my book they lose a star for this whole hookup software thing.On to the camera itself: I'm quite satisfied and might be even more so after I read the User Guide and learn how to do some things that look interesting like setting up certain favored shooting modes to assign to custom setting buttons for quick use.  So far the only thing I've experimented with are the preprogrammed settings.  The zoom is really good and there are assists to help you keep your target in frame and focus on it.  I particularly like that there is a viewfinder as well as the large display that can be used several ways.  I sometimes find it easier to keep the camera steady by using the viewfinder, which allows me to steady the camera against my face.I like the dedicated movie button and ability to take a picture while also taking a video.  The ability to shoot multiple pictures is great, but doesn't ensure perfect focus on them all.  Still it gives you a better chance of getting a good shot during action.  The focus, by the way, is fast and accurate compared to the two other similar cameras I tried.  The FujiFilm and the Olympus were both slower at focusing and the Olympus was annoyingly loud as well.This flash must be raised manually.  If the camera thinks you need it a message on the screen will tell you to raise it, after which it will fire automatically as needed. I like the separate erase button that reduces the risk of accidental erasure when viewing photos.The camera is a bit heavier than the others and is the SLR style bulky shape, but is not as big as a true DSLR camera.  It is easy to hold and the various buttons are well placed.  The battery life is not as long as I would like and can run out in a day of active shooting.  Best to have a backup I think as recharging the battery takes a couple of hours.I'm impressed with picture quality overall.  On a bright day, a cardinal posed for several pictures about 50' away on my back fence.  I was able to zoom until he pretty much filled the frame and I could see every feather distinctly in the finished pictures blown up on my large computer monitor.  The shot of a gopher burrow entrance in my pasture 200' away shows each detailed blade of grass very clearly and if a gopher had stuck his head out I could have seen the pupils of his eyes perfectly.  Some inside flash pictures were excellent, surprisingly so, but the flash didn't seem to carry as far as my smaller PowerShot camera when the same scene was taken with both cameras and compared.  On the other hand if I zoomed to the further location and then took the picture, it turned out very well, so maybe some internal camera intelligence was involved.  User Guide will probably tell.Bottom line, this camera is a keeper.  It's simple enough for this Point & Shoot photographer while also offering extras that will broaden my options and enhance the resulting quality of my pictures--and I might be inspired to learn all about ISO, etc :).

Reviews.Title: 1200mm Zoom!!!!!!! HDR HD video, beautiful photos. Love it!
Reviews.Author: JenniferZ
Reviews.Content: I never dreamed when I bought my first digital camera that someday this would be something obtainable without winning the lottery.  I have had 3 Canon dslr cameras and I loved them each and took thousands of photos with each.  This has inspired me to reach for photos I could not reach with my 1000.00 100-400mm lens.  When the recession hit I had to sell many of my favorite lenses.  This has given me the freedom to reach that far and beyond and still keep my home.  This is a very exciting camera to own.

Reviews.Title: Great electronic -- But SOFT Focus!
Reviews.Author: Howard Dyckoff "Technology writer, journalist...
Reviews.Content: I don't understand why no one has run into problems with the lens focusing system. I am on my 3rd one of these and the focus is still soft. Hair is not that distinct unless I very strongly sharpen the images in post production software. The first one was terrible, the 2nd and 3rd so-so, but softer than my previous 2 digital cameras [a Lunix LZ5 and an Sony H20]. And I am using either "P" mode or "Tv" mode and setting the focus to spot mode.It does produce rather low noise images at ISO 400 and even 600. But I can't get anything really sharp.My guess is the quality control is bad... or few of these 200 plus reviewers here actually look at images at 100 percent.I am reluctantly going to the more expensive Lumix F200 even though i can barely afford it.

Reviews.Title: great ZOOM
Reviews.Author: lori levin
Reviews.Content: better than expected....has some very  nice unexpected new features seeing that I have owned the sx 10 and the sx 30 IS.photographed a sunset in Hawaii .. right up close and personal and accidentally got a  shot of a whale breaking that I could not see 1 mile away!

Reviews.Title: Wow
Reviews.Author: TMCummings
Reviews.Content: I've had several mega-zoom fixed lens cameras through recent years. Nothing come s close to the image quality and reach of this Canon SX50. Yes, the massive zoom is the reason I bought it, and it does not dissappoint. The pics at the longest push of the zoom are flat (zero depth of field) and noisy in anything other than bold bright sunlight. But hey, that target is almost a mile away, and it's in my lap.  The camera is quick, and I get those birds in flight that my previous fixed mega-zooms could only snag with luck. The colors and image quality are most excellent, requiring little if any post production editing. While the auto-scene selection is intuitive and usually correct, I'd really perfer that it let me choose the scene. Sometimes, the choice is wrong and needs to be changed, but the only way around it is to shoot in Program mode. This camera loves low-light shoots.My other fixed lens mega-zooms were useless at dawn and dusk, but this camera does an amazing job, even with moving targets in low light.

Reviews.Title: Great overall camera
Reviews.Author: Dynien
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying that you are buying this camera for the zoom, plain and simple. The 50X zoom is incredible. You can get a lot of shots that are impossible with other point and shoot cameras. The quality at full zoom is excellent. You can get detailed pictures of objects that you normally couldn't with other point and shoot cameras. The image quality remains good even when you throw in the digital zoom although it starts to deteriorate after you get past 100x.A lot of users have complained that the SX50 does not take good pictures in low light. This is true to some degree.  When the camera is set in automatic mode it tends to take dark grainy pictures. It often sets a high ISO and a low shutter speed. This is a especially problematic if you are taking pictures of moving objects. I have found that if you set the camera on manual and adjust the settings to your liking you can take significantly better pictures than the auto mode. This however does not need to be done in better lighting situations as the cameras auto mode works much better than in low light ones.I do recommend that if you intend to use this camera indoors that you invest in an external flash that allows you to bounce the light off the ceiling to get better quality pictures.  Again if you are taking the pictures in an outdoor environment the camera performs wonderfully.  For those of you that are looking to take wildlife pics you wont be disapointed.  How else could you get great closeups of wildlife without having to move close enough to scare them off?I have had no problems with the speed of the zoom and the time it takes to focus on your target. Sometimes it requires you to take your hand off the button and let the camera refucus but that usually only happens in low light situations and at extreme zooms. I have also been able to take a number of close up macro style photos of various objects while blurring the background for that proffesional look.I had to drop off 1 star for the lack of quality of the auto mode in lower light situations but again you can remedy this with a flash or going into manual mode.  Other than that this is a great camera especially for those landscape and wildlife photos that most people looking for a 50x zoom are expecting.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Donald Arthur
Reviews.Content: If you own a Canon SX40, you will really enjoy the SX50. Longer zoom and quicker auto focus. It takes great pictures, but you need to learn the camera to get the best results. It tends to clip the highlights, but after you learn the camera you will eliminate the clipped highlights 95 percent of the time. If  you are a birder this is the camera.  The  Panasonic FZ200 is a great camera also, but for birding its not even a contest. If your shooting birds in the wild you will love the extra reach with the 1200mm lens. If you really learn  this camera and know its limitations you will get some amazing shots.

Reviews.Title: This Canon PowerShot SX50 HS Digital Camera Can Replace a Lot of Your High Dollar Equipment and Easy to Use.
Reviews.Author: Joseph R. Lingle
Reviews.Content: This camera is not a megabuck Professional Camera nor does it sport a $10,000.00  L-Series Lens.  But.......I can tell you that this little camera does a great job in a lot of shooting situations that you cannot do with the large and heavy Pro Equipment without a hassle...  This little guy will make you smile when you see just what it can do, and in most cases you don't have to go in deep debt to buy it.  You can sleep better at night knowing that you spent under $429.00 and are able to shoot stablized pictures from wide angle to faraway telephoto shots with good quality.  I can recommend this camera to anyone... Don't forget that this camera also shoots High Definition Video if you like to do that....

Reviews.Title: Incredible zoom, and an all-around great camera
Reviews.Author: S. Power
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for the 50x optical zoom, which is unheard of in a non-SLR camera.  The zoom doesn't disappoint, but what really impressed me is this camera's other performance attributes, besides just the zoom.  It is fast, relatively light, easy to use, and takes great pictures consistently.I have no complaints at all, and recommend that you check this camera out.

Reviews.Title: So far I love it!
Reviews.Author: Missouri Guy
Reviews.Content: I gave this high ratings at this point because it is everything they promise in the specifications.  I'm not a practicing photo professional and didn't give it a bench test or anything like that.  I just know I like it.  I didn't give it 5 stars because I firmly believe NOTHING is absolutely perfect!It's comfortable in my hands, well-balanced, convenient controls, good looking, the zoom is fantastic (love the stabilztion control for that!), and the macro capabilities are superb.I have used it mostly on AUTO so far, pretty much like a point and shoot, and it does a great job every time.I do wish it had a threaded filter mount on the lens though.  I'd like to keep a UV filter on there to protect the lens and I'm a big fan of what a polarizing filter can do for color saturation and reflection elimination.

Reviews.Title: Would have been a five,but
Reviews.Author: Sade
Reviews.Content: Don't know why they even bothered putting an optical viewfinder on this camera, it is so bad. It's very small and difficult to use. That's doubly bad for me because I prefer to use a viewfinder, especially outside, because it's nearly impossible to see a LCD out in the bright light. They put good viewfinders on their more expensive models so I don't understand. There's one more thing. They put the self timer on the right of the selection wheel,right where your thumb rest, so that you accidentally turn it on constantly; very irritating. Has Canon been bought out by somebody? I've never seen them do this kind of thoughtless engineering. And that's really too bad. It has all the zoom you will ever need. With 1200 mm optical, I don't even use the digital zoom. The images are very sharp. But the viewfinder blows it.

Reviews.Title: Better than SX40HS
Reviews.Author: LeeG
Reviews.Content: It has exceeded my expectations. Having owned the previous versions, I especially purchased it due to its Raw capabilities, but so far I haven't used the Raw that much. At  this time it only seems to open in Canon Raw Processing, but not in my Photoshop.The camera appears to be more professional and rugged in appearance than the previous models. The 50x zoom is awesome and I've even used digital  zoom with excellent results. Doing mostly wildlife photography, the camera meets my requirements of light weight in the field. The photo results easily compare with my Canon SLR's that lately,  seem to remain home unused. ISO range has been improved, but the max lens opening has been reduced, however it hasn't appeared to make a difference since the image stabilization is so good. The ergonomics are improved and the camera is extremely easy to use in the field. I would recommend this camera to anyone wanting to do wildlife photography, on a limited budget, wanting good optics, lighter weight in equipment, and expecting more than 90% of his images to be as expected. I'll add to the review after taking many more pictures. After using this camera for the last few months, its even better than I expected.I'm now using a 32GB card as I' m now running off many more pictures, especially when I use the multiple shot scene mode, that I really enjoy using in the refuges. And as for moon shots, even with some digital Zoom, at 100X, the stabilization is so good that only one out of five shots is discarded. As you can tell, the camera has made photography even more fun. Those people that complain about a few things should read their manual more thoroughly. There's an awful lot in it about using this camera and it should be read if you wan't to get the best out of this camera.

Reviews.Title: The New PowerShot SX50 HS Meets My Expectations
Reviews.Author: d crenshaw
Reviews.Content: The SX50 HS is the third PowerShot camera I've purchased after the S3 and SX10 and it is by far the best Canon megazoom camera yet. I've taken over 700 photos so far and I'm please with both the quality of the images and the ease of operation.I have yet to try out all its features but I'm very impressed with the detail found within 40 - 50X when shooting. However, I strongly advise using a tripod when shooting at the maximum focal range due to the extreme sensitivity of the camera's stabilization features. It would be interesting to take shots with a Panasonic FZ200 to see how it composes images with the f2.8 aperture available but I definitely have no regrets in purchasing the Canon.  I've been a big fan of Canon since my younger days with a Canon A-1 35mm camera (which I still have) and am glad that the company is still innovating great products for amateur photo enthusiasts like myself.

Reviews.Title: amazing zoom just isn't enough for me
Reviews.Author: SkyGirlUAL "skygirlual"
Reviews.Content: I love this zoom, it is incredible, and I'm going to cry a little when I return this camera! However, after trying all of the modes, I'm not getting quality portraits.I envisioned a camera that would take great family shots and also feature my little soccer player without having to lug a monster lens around. The zoom is amazing. I could not be more impressed with it. Brilliant, clear, detailed shots of animals at the zoo using the zoom. (Check out my picture of a swan with water droplets on her feathers.)Sadly, only a few family/portraits came out in the quality I expect.Also, outdoor/sunny shots lost details in the whites. I have a white dog and she glows in every picture even when sitting still. It is not a motion/blur. I have also noticed a purple haze between high contrast areas. However, I am happy to report the flash is adequate and did not wash out my subjects.Overall, If I could afford to keep this just for the zoom and to use for sports, I would.

Reviews.Title: Canon SX50 HS - All the  time camera
Reviews.Author: Heriberto -Cali, Colombia
Reviews.Content: I bought to AMAZON the Canon SX50 HS camera in November 01-2012,the camera handling is very easy,for birds photos is a stunning camera, excelent colors with hight imagen definition, when drop the photos to my PC, I and can compare them with those taken wiht my Canon T1i with EF 70-200 mm f/4L USM lens, the bird pictures are very close.For traveling, wildlife and sight-seeing,Canon POWER SHOT SX50 HS is the right and not heavy all the time camera.

Reviews.Title: A great, lightweight and powerful little camera.
Reviews.Author: Fezz
Reviews.Content: My main camera is a Nikon D7000 which I love but is for some reason getting heavier as I get older!  I wanted a camera that was light weight, flexible and produced good pictures.  I read a number of positive reports about it on my photography forum and decided to give it a try.  Wow!  I love it!  It goes with me everywhere for 90% of my picture taking.  It is  light, easy to use and has terrific zoom capabilities at 50X.  I still use my favorite D7000 but mostly at home or where I don't have to have it hanging around my neck for hours on end.  I highly recommend it!

Reviews.Title: Great option for amatures
Reviews.Author: George Lyons "gl"
Reviews.Content: I do not shoot photos often. But when I do during travel and vacation times, I take lots of pictures of all varieties--from wide angle to long-distance telephotos, under all kinds of conditions.I have been impressed by how much faster this camera is as compared to  Canon's earlier SX35, which I have used for several years. I have not yet spent the time I should reading the owner's manual. But most of the settings are intuitive and the results are almost always satisfying enough to impress most who see the images the camera generates.In the past I often missed photo-opportunities with my Canon SLR digital camera due to changing lenses and recalling how the thing worked. Now the only shots I miss are due to the brief time-lapse needed between shots to write the image to the SD card.

Reviews.Title: An excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Don Smith
Reviews.Content: I have read many reviews about this camera, probably more than I had to but before I buy something I want to make sure I'm getting what I pay for. I knew I wanted a super zoom camera but since there are now so many different models available, the choice was a difficult one. The reason why I chose this two year old model over a newer one was that I found the sample images taken with this camera were better than others I have seen. That, coupled with some very good reviews written by people who have been using the camera for a while, prompted me to buy one. I have had it for over a month and I have not been disappointed. I bought the camera primarily for wildlife pictures and not only have I found the results very good, some of my friends who are avid photographers have also been very, very impressed. I would even say shocked, at the quality this camera is capable of producing.I won't go into detail about all the cameras features and settings because that is available all over the net and even here at Amazon. If it seems like I'm going overboard about the sx50 it's just that I have been so pleased with this purchase and have been having so much fun with this camera, I strongly recommend it to anyone who loves to take great pictures.Remember, a picture is worth a thousand words so check out some samples around the net and see, despite some one star reviews (which I don't understand why they are there) this really is an excellent camera.

Reviews.Title: Knockout for distant nature photography
Reviews.Author: Cory Chiappone "Chia"
Reviews.Content: It is incredibly light. Unlike other cameras I have owned I always carry this one with me while hiking, birding etc and avoid the to carry or not to carry debate. The zoom is incredible and takes photos super-fast. I like that the settings are adjustable and being able to record video with 50x optical zoom is great. The picture quality is not of a large SLR but still good. The only real complaint is it is not very good at taking pictures of birds in flight; otherwise this camera is a knockout for distant nature photography.

Reviews.Title: Replaces DSLR
Reviews.Author: Pair "PR"
Reviews.Content: I hesitated for this camera but it is so much easier for travel than the big DSLR with all the lens. Quality is good, it is made in Japan so I trust more in its lasting life.

Reviews.Title: I lOVE my new SX50 HS
Reviews.Author: Bob S
Reviews.Content: Low cost, compact, lightweight, takes great photos, and has a 50x optical zoom.  What's not to love?  Seriously, folks, I'm really impressed with it. I'll try to post some sample photos.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for Birding.
Reviews.Author: M. Burnett
Reviews.Content: This camera is the perfect camera for birding....  50x reach is amazing for getting ID shots of your birds.  Been using this camera since March.  It does have the typical Powershot issues with focus in low light, but the tradeoffs are worth it.  I do question it's durability but for the price you can not have it all.  I would buy it again for my use, which is a light mobile field camera for birding.

Reviews.Title: Very good bridge camera
Reviews.Author: Jamie Katz "Jamie Katz, reader and writer"
Reviews.Content: Really fun camera comes up with some great shots.  Doesn't substitute for a DSLR, don't kid yourself--won't take action shots well, or in low-light.  But this is easy to carry, comes up with accurate, vibrant, in-focus shots from all over--I have a lovely photo taken at full extension of a bright cardinal sitting in snow taken last winter that looks great.  Great travel camera, as well as for other uses.  It's limitation for travel purposes is that it won't fit in your pocket, but it's still easy to carry and will get you a range of cameras that only a few cameras can pull off well.

Reviews.Title: TAKES GREAT PICTURES
Reviews.Author: Nancy Nielsen
Reviews.Content: This is a nice camera. It takes real good quality pictures. The only complaint I have is that the view finder is really bad. It not clear, rather fuzzy. The view finder does not fit the quality of the camera.

Reviews.Title: LOVE IT
Reviews.Author: Mary S.
Reviews.Content: This is one of the best cameras I ever purchased. Totally worth the price. The video feature is crystal clear and the pictures are flawless. Obviously it's not a point and shoot so it's a little bulky, but once you see how the pictures turn out, you will totally forget about it!

Reviews.Title: Photo quality and zoom are beyond belief - even set on AUTO ...
Reviews.Author: CindyG
Reviews.Content: I love this camera.  I've been using it since late July, so through 3 family vacation events countless garden shots and an amazing peak foliage in VT trip. I bought this as a step up from my Canon Elph (SD 1100 IS) which I also love - and still use. I'm a 50+ year old mom who has aimed for simple, minimal thought needed for most of my picture taking years.You can't think about the f stop and keep them out of the lake at the same time.  The Elph got me through years of field trips and hikes and other kid stuff that I just didn't want to have to engage the brain, but still get great photos-and fits in my pocket. I got frustrated with the lack of zoom though, so started looking.  There are lots of choices out there, but when I got my more technically minded and camera savvy husband to check my top 5 choices (by way of what I thought I wanted and customer reviews), I gave him the parameters of - least customer complaints, maximum zoom, and stick with Canon if you can because I am already used to their symbols and menu navigation nuisances. He agreed with my top choice despite strong leanings towards Nikon. They will always be faster, but seriously, I'm not that picky. I will never be a professional photographer, but this camera could be used by one. I am still working on reading the manual for a bunch of presets I can make, but it is also totally possible to just set it on auto and use it. I have photos of loons where you can see every feather and the drops of lake water on them.  I will say that, before we headed for foliage in VT - I bought a set of filters and adapter ring for it. Just wanted the polarizing filter, but the others may be useful and it was under $30 for the set. Incredible photos, easy to use and a completely reasonable price, and I know I have MUCH to learn to be using it at full capacity!

Reviews.Title: Versatile Camera
Reviews.Author: Leigh
Reviews.Content: Very powerful camera.  It is always the first thing I'd pull out when I see something interesting, mainly because the reach and good image quality.  It is also a camera for you to spend quality time in the park, near a pond, or any where.

Reviews.Title: Love this Camera
Reviews.Author: Pamela Davis
Reviews.Content: Just got back from a 3 week vacation and realized would like to have a camera I could get great clarity from but not have to always take the time to switch lens.  I missed a few opportunities for a great shot on my vacation while chnging the lens on my camera.  with this one I will be ready and have a equal ot better zoom than I do on my current Cannon.  Couldnt believe the Camera arrived so quickly.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Andrew Bonikowsky
Reviews.Content: I am delighted with the Canon Powershot SX50 camera. It has tons of practical options, like for example, the leveling device.

Reviews.Title: LOVE, LOVE, LOVE IT!
Reviews.Author: Betty Dallas "Beaches and Dreams"
Reviews.Content: Received this camera yesterday and have fallen head over heels in love.  That being said, please know I am a point and shoot type of gal who lives on a lake with lots of wildlife hanging about.  It's perfect.  I played with it for several hours and have found some fun filters, e.g., a fisheye filter among others.  For anyone looking for easy to carry and easy to shoot, this would be the one for you.  Zoom capabilities are incredible, even in the digital mode.  The one thing I learned in a photo course a long time ago is "read the manual."  I'll be doing that over the next few weeks so I can take full advantage of everything this little camera has to offer... I may even get out of AUTO mode someday :)

Reviews.Title: Even better than the SX40 HS
Reviews.Author: Floyd J Jackson
Reviews.Content: I loved the Canon SX 40 HS but bought the SX 50 HS also as I wanted the ability to shoot RAW, use remote triggering and several other features the 40 didn't have.  Also it corrected the location of the Playback button which I was always hitting by mistake. But, sorry to say, they now have located the movie button in an equally bad place  which I will have to learn to deal with. I have 5 Canon  Digital Bridge cameras and 1 DSLR. This SX 50 HS is now my main "walk around camera " .

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: scribe
Reviews.Content: I have a DSLR, but wanted a camera to take hiking or on travel where I could take a variety of shots without lugging around several lenses.  After much research, I setted on the SX50.  It received rave reviews in most places that I researched and were recommended over some newer, more expensive models.Experiences so far:Outdoors:Outdoors in takes very crisp, clear pictures with excellent color tone.  The 50x zoom is amazing and has assisted getting some good wildlife shots.Indoors:I was worried as there are a couple of reviews here and there that complain about indoor conditions.  I, however, have been very surprised and pleased with the quality.  I have also heard that this could vary by camera.  A coworker also bought this model and his indoor/lowlight shots were so bad that he returned it.  When I showed him mine he was amazed it was even the same camera.  I even recently took this camera on a trip to NY and took shots with no flash in a museum where the only light was the exhibits and the rest of the room was dark and they came out very well.All in all, I can't recommend this camera enough.  In the superzoom class it is a great camera at a great value.

Reviews.Title: VLOGGERS Camera!!!
Reviews.Author: Tech and Gear Fan
Reviews.Content: The top, High End, Point and Shoot Cameras, are all very similar..Sony/Nikon/Canon/Olympus..this is the only one that still has a view screen that pivots all the way around for you to see a self portrait or a Vlog or a Picture with your Kids...etc...for ME, that made this My ONLY choice, as we vlog on youtube and send Family videos around on Facebook......why on earth none of the other camera makers think this is important is beyond me. Amazing Camera/zoom/picture & Video quality?...YES!...they ALL do..but if you vlog..and happen to care about what is in your screen...get this camera...hope this humble opinion was helpful to the millions of people active on Youtube..or sharing videos on Facebook.

Reviews.Title: excellent bridge camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Cynthia L. Rosa
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for the zoom. It takes amazing outdoor photos; birds, insects, animals and more. Even photos of the moon. This is what I bought it for and am quite pleased with the high quality images I have gotten. I have MS and deal with bad tremors which can make taking a centered image/clarity challenging. With this camera I rarely get blurry pics from unsteady hands.Pros:quick turn on/start up time (is ready to shoot pretty quickly)good time Auto focusvery good image stabilizationrechargable batteryexcellent image quality and zoomeasy to useVideo quality is goodCons:Low light photos/video with & without flash are not up to the quality I would expect from Canon..i.e. noise at anything over iso 600.Over ISO 800 is often quite grainy.Likewise with the zoom...anything over 800mm(60-75x) can be soft-edged (mild noise) and the higher you get to 100x zoom or (1200mm) the greater the noise.These are the ONLY 2 reasons I did not give this camera 5 stars. (my panasonic lumix tz8 was much worse that the Canon sx50)There has not been a single time I've regretted buying this camera. It is well worth the money. I cannot afford a DLSR and this camera is a perfect compromise.

Reviews.Title: Best "point & shoot" I've ever owned!
Reviews.Author: Barry L. Hobbs
Reviews.Content: Let me be honest. I originally wanted the Panasonic FZ200. But the price skyrocketed over $100 in a couple of weeks. I honestly could not justify spending well over $500 for a bridge camera, although the f2.8 aperture over the entire zoom was screaming for me to get it. The Canon SX50 was my second choice, mainly for its insane 50x zoom. I picked it up for $369. Low light shooting and long reach have always been big draws, along with photo quality for me as a wildlife enthusiast. Turns out that this camera isn't too bad in low light either, although the trade off is higher ISO and grainier shots. Sure, I've had several DSLR's and I carried large lenses around for years. I finally got tired of all that bulk and decided to accept the trade off in a smaller sensor and photo quality. I'm not a professional and don't require full sensor quality. I opted for the SX50 based on pretty darned good reviews and the crazy long reach of the lens. Based on the many test shots I've taken both indoors and out, I am very happy with the performance of this camera! I may not have the critical expectations of a professional reviewer, but I know what I like and this bridge camera satisfies. Photo quality is very good and the 50x (200x digital) reach is incredible! That reach will bring that bird or coyote in the distance up close and personal. Also, remember that any camera is only as good as the photographer. If you don't know how to use a camera to its full potential, don't blame the camera! The SX50 is the best sub-DSLR camera I've owned to date and it serves my purposes quite well.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic
Reviews.Author: C. M. Cotton "Chris Cotton"
Reviews.Content: I was given this camera to test and then own via the amazon Vine programme.I used to be a photography buff in the age of the SLR's, buying ISO film and exchanging filters and lenses to ensure the correct photo was produced. One would then take the roll of film to the shop and a week later you would see if what you took turned out OK. With today's digital cameras all these issues have been taken out of the equation with the compact digital cameras. There are still constraints with most compacts I have used, which is compromise between picture quality, the ability to manually set the camera for creativity purposes and the ability to change lenses to allow great macro or zoom shots. I have had 3 very good quality Panasonic Lumix cameras, the last being a TZ30. Whilst these compacts were good, they did not serve all the purposes I wanted in a camera.The Canon SX50 is not a compact camera and it is not a DSLR, but it is something in between. It is small and compact compared to a DSLR but has so many features included in it, you would think you are using a DSLR. The biggest difference is that this camera does not have inter changeable lenses, it comes with a magnificent 50X zoom, 4.3-215.0mm 1:3.4-6.5 USM canon wide angle lens. Having chosen Panasonic cameras in the past because they use a leica lens, all I can say is this lens is every bit as good in terms of picture quality as anything Panasonic can produce. The zoom is breathtaking in its clarity at 50X zoom. The zoom itself is very quiet and fast. The camera also has a 100X digital zoom which does not compromise the picture quality too much. In essence the lens is stunning with what it can do, allowing for maximum creativity in such a small camera.I experimented with this camera and its zoom lens. What blew me away was a shot I took in a totally dark room, focusing on a balloon with print on at 50X zoom. The result was a flawless picture whilst using the Auto mode. The picture had a minute amount of grain and the printing on the balloon was perfectly reproduced. The Panasonic cameras I have been used to, could not take such a perfect photo, as they are very poor at taking night shots. All I can say is every night shot I have taken with this camera has been virtually perfect.If the more experienced photographer wants greater freedom than that offered by the AUTO mode, there is a myriad of different settings which allow everything from fully automatic, semi automatic, differing shutter and apeture priorities, scene modes, JPEG and RAW modes which allow virtually every function of the camera to be set by the user. I have never used a digital camera which allows for so much control by the user.I must say I am an AUTO setting fan and on this mode picture quality is outstanding and with a little bit of adjustment to the menu, it eliminates red eye problems, has face recognition technology and even gives a warning if someone in a photo has their eyes shut. I have found whilst set in auto mode it has chosen the apeture and shutter speed perfectly virtually every time. It is almost impossible to take a bad photo in AUTO mode. I cannot express how impressed I am with this camera whilst using this mode.The Video function records in HD and again offers superb quality pictures and allows for the zoom function whilst filming. The sound quality is also very good and is HD.The LCD screen is large and very clear. Once set up it can display a multitude of information which helps the photographer who wants to use the RAW mode. There is a small viewfinder but I prefer the multi angle, flipable LCD screen.The quality of the camera appears to be top notch. Although it is made from plastic it appears to be quality plastic and is nicely balanced in how it feels to hold. The grip could do with being rubberised, but this is a minor problem.The battery needs charging for 2 hours and lasts for about 350 shots. It comes with a strap and lens cover. You will need to buy an SD card and I would suggest nothing less than a class 10 card from a good manufacturer, so that it can cope with all the features of this amazing camera.There is one downside and for the life of me I cannot understand why Canon did this, the internal flash needs to be manually raised and does not pop out automatically when needed. There is a traditional horseshoe flash point on top of the camera and maybe the non auto pop of the flash may have something to do with the ability to use a more powerful flash gun. Non auto pop up may be there so avoiding damage to the internal flash if it flipped up whilst a flash gun was being used.I can only find minor flaws with this camera, which are far outweighed by the beautiful pictures it produces, myriad of functions it has and ease of use in AUTO mode. Whilst I have used a DSLR and not liked it because of the lens constraints, I have used this little beauty and loved every minute of it. The zoom is outstanding and the lens produces almost perfect results. I could go on and on about how much I adore this camera, but I guess the reader gets how I feel about it. It is not cheap, but you get what you pay for and with this beauty it is well justified.Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Powershot SX50
Reviews.Author: Andrew Bishop
Reviews.Content: Wow.We bought this as a backup camera to my DSLR for a trip to Africa on safari. I maxed out at 300mm (on a DX camera so that actually equivalent to about 450mm) This camera has far more optical reach.I took some fantastic photos of the Full moon,and my wife also got some great shots at the full 50X optical zoom.The stabilization worked really well (or I'd never have got the moon shots)I have only owned a DSLR for a year, and bought it with this safari trip in mind, until then I have always just had point and shoot Canon power-shots, smaller the better, and been very happy.If this camera was available before I bought the DSLR, (and I'd known about it), I may never have bought the DSLR.Several people from the trip have gone out and bought this camera once they played with it on the trip.My wife and I took the same shot at the same time on one occasion, having printed both out side by side,  - the DSLR is the better color photo, but it was close. - and had you never seen the DSLR version, you would be over the moon with the shot.Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Absolutely amazing lens
Reviews.Author: Setter Dog "Jack"
Reviews.Content: I primarily use a Sony a77 and a Panasonic G5 for long range wildlife photography, locally and in the National Parks. The longest manageable lens I have is a  Pany 100-300mm, 600mm equivalent. I was posting on several forums, asking about long zoom options and got lots of suggestions,..... all for very heavy and expensive lenses that would give me 750mm reach. One member suggested,..."try the Canon SX50, you might be surprised at the results."Well folks, I did try it and I was pleasantly surprised. I've used the SX50 almost daily, side by side with my Sony and Panasonic. The lens at 1200mm optical zoom is amazing, not only for reach but also for clarity. Even 2X digital zoom (2400mm) is very, very good. It's hard to tell it's digital zoom. All this for less than half the price of a 750mm option for my other cameras. It's hard to even imagine the power of this lens until you've seen it. It's my go to camera for distant birds and wildlife.Although I rate this camera a 5, that is exclusively for the lens. It is not the best all around camera in it's class. For kids' sports, for example, it comes up short in the continuous shooting modes. It does not have in camera panorama or high speed high def video like others in it's class.The image quality is better than any of the other small sensor cameras I've used. The long reach and high image quality will make this a camera that most people will enjoy. When discussed on forums, a frequent comment, which I share is,....."This is the most fun camera I've ever had!"Jack

Reviews.Title: Amazing Zoom
Reviews.Author: Blind Lemon Pie
Reviews.Content: This camera has been amazing for my purpose as an amateur photography enthusiast wanting a large zoom for wildlife pics. The 50x optical zoom (1200mm equivalent) has been awesome and allowed me to get high quality shots from very long distances. Even the 100x (optical plus digital zoom) has produced some surprisingly usable pictures with good detail. Image stabilization works well enough allow me to take good hand-held pictures at full optical zoom, but a tripod is always preferred if available. On the wide-angle side, the camera zooms out to a very good 24mm equivalent lens.  The manual controls are great to have (shutter speed, apeture). The digital level feature on the display was very useful to ensure a level shot. The camera has many other useful features (multiple focusing modes, ability to control the power of the flash, compensation to make pics brighter or darker). But the bottom line of cameras is always the picture quality - and this camera has provided consistently good pics with good exposures, good color balance and good detail.  Battery life isn't the greatest - on one occasion I needed to change batteries in a single day, so be sure to buy a spare.  Overall this camera has been perfect for me - small enough to to travel with, light enough to take on hikes, versatile lens (24mm - 1200mm), good quality pictures, without the hassle of needing (and lugging around) multiple lenses, and at a price MUCH less than a DSLR.  I am very pleased with this purchase and recommend this camera for anyone wanting a big zoom.

Reviews.Title: Canon powershot sx50
Reviews.Author: Jim Saccomanno
Reviews.Content: this camera handles easily and very well. take shots very accurately and fast. for the price its a great buy

Reviews.Title: Love the zoom
Reviews.Author: Dixie F. Durward "Doodle"
Reviews.Content: The distance to take a picture is amazing and so far I've been able to take graduation pictures of a grandson even sitting in the stands.

Reviews.Title: Canon Quality--Just A Great all around camera
Reviews.Author: W. Peterson
Reviews.Content: This Canon camera is just Great and is one of the best all around all occasion cameras that I have ever owned. I take about 12,000 photos a year and performance is very important as well as battery life. Everything from the very closeup to using the 50 time zoom come out.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for Traveling
Reviews.Author: Jon
Reviews.Content: I love this camera for traveling. Takes great pictures and is compact enough to easily carry on trips. Definitely recommend.

Reviews.Title: This is amazing.
Reviews.Author: Cleo
Reviews.Content: If you looking for a great camera, this is the one. It has so many amazing features on it. Now am no professional but I can tell you, you will feel like one. I have done so much research on canon, I really did not have a lot of money to shell out but I wanted something close. Judging from doing so much research this camera has it all. Auto for those unsure, and so many options for the advance people. What was amazing was all the options and the feel.In the beginning of my journey I started out with the sx500 this was nice and compact, but I wanted something more. I like the fact of all the features and the zoom. In regards to the sx500 I returned it, the sx50 has so much more to offer without the price tag.Another thing is I had back surgery so there is no way I could carry all of the equipment around with me. I am able to do so much. Pictures are great and the video is great. I will admit I had to buy books to help me understands how to shoot and understanding what all the features can do.In conclusion if you looking for something close to professional for a great price this is for you. If you are new to photogrophy or just having a hobby this camera wil work. Another thing is I love shooting landscapes, wildlife and family. Recommendations get some books for beginners they really help. Read the the instructions they have so much to offer. For the money worth it.

Reviews.Title: finally A real camera even I can use
Reviews.Author: wendy rodgers
Reviews.Content: My husband has purchased many cameras for me. I love taking pictures of the family, nature, our golden retrievers.... I was not satisfied with the zoom on my GE or the quality on my kodak. I wanted a point and shoot that took pictures like a dslr well this is that camera. The zoom is amazing, the clarity phanominal, and very, very user friendly. Still pretty light even for a larger camera. I absolutely love the consecutive shots I can take when the dogs or kids are playing in the sports mode you never miss a goofy face or the perfect jump with the dogs.  I highly recommend this as user friendly and professional grade pics..

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: footsie
Reviews.Content: Extreme zoom.......Great pictures under all conditions.  MUCH BETTER ALL AROUND AS COMPARED TO MY Cannon PowerShot S3 IS digital camera...............

Reviews.Title: Very good Camera !
Reviews.Author: HUGO FABIO SANABRIA AGUILAR
Reviews.Content: Excellent camera, very powerful zoom so I can take pictures to distant airplanes and landscapes with very good results. Zoom Framing Assist and the image stabilizer works remarkably well. I highly recommend  this product, great price and quality, and I will enjoy it during many years taking pictures and videos of many beautiful places in my country, Colombia.Thank you amazon.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful zoom camera
Reviews.Author: V. Huang
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to use on a recent trip to Costa Rica.  The last dslr that I have owned is the Nikon D90, but it was just too big and bulky to carry with me on vacation.  I had the Panasonic FZ150 which I really loved, but there were times when I felt limited by the zoom so when the SX50 was announced, I seriously considered it and the FZ200.  I had some concerns about the slower lens of the SX50 but in the end, the superior zoom capabilities won out and I bought the SX50.  I wasn't sorry!  We took over 1000 pictures during our trips and the camera performed beautifully.  It was able to take pictures of monkeys and birds in the backlit and at times low light rainforest canopy.  Overall, I am very happy with my purchase.  I love taking pictures of wildlife and this camera is great for that with its 50x optical zoom.  The only reason why I did not give it 5 stars is the low resolution EVF and the very annoying feature that when you take a still photo during video this causes the video to black out and pause when the photo is taken.  This is extremely annoying and caused me to ruin quite a few videos early on in our trip.  I don't understand why Canon does this.  I have the Sony RX100 which allows you to take 16 mp stills during video without disrupting the video.  If you are interested in seeing the photos/videos we took on our trip, please message me and I will send you the Youtube link.

Reviews.Title: Better each time!
Reviews.Author: William A. Schultz
Reviews.Content: I had the SX10, which was great at the time with a 20X zoom.  Then when the SX30 cameout with the 35X zoom, I got that one.  It similar to the SX10, but the 35X optical zoom.  This SX50 HS is the best of the group!  I LOVE the 50X, 1200 mm optical zoom.  WOW!  And, not in the action mode 13 frames a second, compared to the previous 3.  Others who are more knowledgeable will likely have other things they also like, but for wildlife, to get this zoom without carrying a lens that would need a cart, is really something.  So far I'm very impressed with the images.I've also liked these cameras because of the ability to use the viewfinder or the display on the back, which faces the camera body when not in use.  Great for protecting the screen.  The display also rotates to allow for many ways to hold the camera.The Amazon price was amazing for a recent introduced camera!Bill

Reviews.Title: Great Buy
Reviews.Author: Bob Anderson "Bob"
Reviews.Content: Meets all expectations and more, reach out and touch someone!! Brings things into view that you never knew existed. Have owned sx20, sx30, this is the best!

Reviews.Title: Good but lacking...
Reviews.Author: Roberto Vicente "bodhiu"
Reviews.Content: A very good prosumer camera.  A good buy for a beginner to middle range photographer, but not for the advanced photographer.  Excellent zoom lens for bird shots and good jpg (better than RAW development in this case!).  Faster than the SX40, lighter and overall improved.  You will need a monopod or tripod to shoot with this as that is what I carry.  Battery life is excellent as I took 1,000 shots over four hours (however, I turned off the camera when not shooting).  In fairness to the SX50, most of the shots I took would have been impossible with its superior zoom reach.  Probably the best bridge camera on the market.However, the camera should be considered legally blind as it can't focus in dim light, shadows or on dark subjects.  Really searches.  No in camera stitch editing (why bother having it).  A great disappointment is that for the high end price, Canon doesn't include video and computer cables--talk about cheap!!

Reviews.Title: Not for low light or cloudy conditions
Reviews.Author: Wolfhere
Reviews.Content: I have graduated from models SX10 IS, SX30 IS and SX40 HS. I give the SX40 HS high marks. I bought the SX50 HS in hopes of being able to use the 50X zoom with some competence. I have a decent tripod and the Canon remote. But when shooting on a cloudy day (low light), a very high percentage of shots are trash. No focus. I realize that I am an amateur, but have fun taking shots of nearby eagles. I have not yet tried continuous auto focus or manual  focus. And there is still no Shortcourse (Dennis P. Curtin) to guide me in the right direction.I am willing to wait a little longer, in hopes of getting what I want out of this camera. I do not want to wait too long and am unsure as to the return policy. Amazon, can you help?

Reviews.Title: Zoom is magnificent, while lacking in Macro, Panorama and High Speed shooting.
Reviews.Author: Kolin's Travels "Global Nomad, World Traveler...

Reviews.Title: Canon Has done it AGAIN!!!
Reviews.Author: John C
Reviews.Content: I've been buying Canon cameras for as long as I can remember.  This camera came out just two months after I purchased my SX10, which I have taken well over 10,000 shots with.  A friend told me all about this camera as he had the patience to wait.  I've seen many of his photos and I have to say it has some really fantastic features.  While I love the super zoom, one had better have it mounted on a tripod.  The Image Stabilization (IS) just doesn't do much to improve the photo if shot hand held and zoomed out (equivalent 1200mm) maximum.  I have come to appreciate the NB-10L 7.4v--920mAh battery pack & quick charger that comes standard with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Above expectations
Reviews.Author: OZ "Falconz"
Reviews.Content: After a couple of months of searching and researching I settled on the SX50, apart from the 50x digital zoom, the competitive price played a major role in making this decision.I happen to be traveling through an international airport and I saw it in the duty free at 805$ (!!!), Best Buy price is 429$ so you can see how this had a major influence on my decision.to start with the most negative part which made me give it 4 instead of 5 stars: I have to pop the flash manually, I was surprised that a camera of this caliber has a manual flash not automatic since I can control it through the camera software.Although I read several reviews on Amazon before I purchased it non of them mentioned that.Other than that I would have given it 5 stars, the camera snaps great shots, and I used it while attending the Indianapolis MotoGP race a couple of weeks ago in sport mode where it snaps several shots then you can pick the most beautiful ones.If you are like me; fed up with point & shoot tiny cameras and its time for changing your 2-3 years old one with something more professional and not willing to pay more than 500$ (that was my budget), not willing to go into changing lenses to shoot a few shots now and then, and you can live with the fact that you have to pop the flash manually when needed (the camera will ask you do so if needed) this is the camera of choice.I hope this helps.

Reviews.Title: We love it
Reviews.Author: KS90292
Reviews.Content: We bought this right before our trip to Bora Bora.  We are so happy with it.  It is a really amazing camera.

Reviews.Title: Just Fantastic!
Reviews.Author: Felipe Chavarri
Reviews.Content: I can't believe it, just amazing pictures and a super mega zoom. Really It's just fantastic. I'm not a pro but the pictures I took really rocks. Thank you Canon!

Reviews.Title: A major step forward
Reviews.Author: teej1010
Reviews.Content: Once again, Canon has out done themselves.  I've owned Canon cameras for over 40 years and I'm sold on the brand.  Over that period of time I've progressed from simple point & shoot to film SLRs to digital point & shoot to digital SLRs.  I'm now at that point where I want great capability without having to carry all of the equipment and lenses.  I tried the SX30 and was very happy with the compact size and versatility.  The 30x optical lens was very good although there was some distortion at max magnification.  It also was not real great in low light situations.  With the SX50 Canon has corrected those issues and the 50x optical lens is unreal.  Even at max magnification, the image stabilization keeps the image clear and in focus.  Great camera, especially for anyone who travels.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera with a MEGA ZOOM!!!
Reviews.Author: D. Black
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera after first trying out the lesser sx500 model which I promptly returned. The sx50 model was a big upgrade!!! The picture quality is very good and the zoom allowed me to see craters on the moon! Simply amazing. The articulating screen is another big plus. I'm very happy with this camera and it CMOS sensor handles ISO noise very well!!!

Reviews.Title: Quite an amazing camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Adrian
Reviews.Content: I have a Pentax K-5 which i consider my main camera. But like many people, I find it gets a bit burdomsome carrying around numerous lenses, flashes, etc. I've been through a number of superzooms before and not been impressed enough to keep them long term (Nikon s10, Nikon P90/100, Fujifilm HS10) but the thought of a 1200mm lens made me bite the bullet again.This time I think I have a keeper, at least until the next model comes out!I bought it at 11.38pm on a Saturday night, then used it for a 6 hour hike, followed by dinner, taking about 200 photos, and 4 x 3 second videos.The good: - Really sharp photos. I was amazed by some close ups of leaves and seed pods that were about 20 metres away from me. I truly thought they were as sharp as my dslr - Reasonable weight, ok for holding and carrying - Good battery life. The battery indicator was still at 3 bars after the 200 photos (battery indicator has 3 bars- 3 bars- full, 1 bar- nearly empty) - Good build quality. - Smooth and quick lens zooming - Quick and accurate auto focus lock, at least during the day. Really impressed. - Nice to have some control over shutter speed and aperture. - LCD is sharp and accurate, even though it's not the max resolution you can see on some other cameras. Swivel screen is versatile too.The not so good: - It's good that there's a dedicated video button. It's not so good that it's positioned in a place I bumped it several times, hence my 4 x 3 sec videos. - On/off switch not quite in easy reach- would love to be able to just use a finger to flick a switch on/off, but I usually have to reach across and look to press- just takes an extra second, and I find I miss that bird flapping it's wings. I'll get used to the layout I suspect. - Deleting photos. So far, I've only been able to delete one photo at a time, on the camera. The only method I can think of for deleting multiples is to connect to the computer, go to the File directory and click them. - Speaking of computer, there was no included USB cable in my box. I think I read someone else said this too. If this is normal, it's a strange ommission. - The battery latch cover is a bit light. Twice during the hike it got bumped and the camera turned off, as there is no internal additional battery latch/lock and the battery moved. - The 24mm is not really 24mm, perhaps more like 30mm. I wouldn't rely on this for true wide angle photos.Overall, the SX50 is a great camera to have around during the day, and for travelling. It's capable, takes really good quality photos, and the large zoom allows you to compose photos you'd never have considered when using your normal 28-120mm type lenses.

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot SX50 Digital Cameria Review
Reviews.Author: John D. Jansen Jr. "jDj"
Reviews.Content: I have been using cameras for years but have never seen the ease of opperation for this camera.  With very little experience, the average person can take photos of high quality and wonderful movies.  I'm stiil exploring the camera but, am really satisfied with 1) the ease of starting to use the camera, 2) the ability to use the zoom feature and get great in-focus photos and, 3) the everyday ease of operation. I would recommend this unit for the experienced, as well as the novice photographer.

Reviews.Title: Redeeming
Reviews.Author: G
Reviews.Content: I had a Nikon S9700 that I really liked and lost, followed by a Canon SX170 that I disliked and returned, followed by this camera. This camera, the Canon SX50 HS, has turned me around on Canon.First off if you are buying this, you probably are looking for the zoom.  The 50x optical zoom is incredible and unlike previous cameras I have owned, the additional digital zoom is not totally worthless.  The digital zoom adds a mild amount of noise to the picture, but with a stable hand it is still possible to take a relatively high quality picture.When left to its own devices this camera fairs well in both well lit and night time outdoor scenes.  Where it seems to have the most trouble is high contrast scenes, like trying to take a picture into dimly lit building from a bright outdoors.  I think the Nikon had a leg up on this camera in this particular situation, but I was more interested in the zoom.Nighttime pictures with this camera come out impressive, much more so than the SX170.  I have a bit a trouble getting the camera to take sharp daytime pictures, but I am learning and there are many examples of amazing daytime images from more skilled individuals [...]  There is definitely a lot to be gained by manually tuning settings with this camera [...]  All that said, this probably isn't the camera to try and capture great shots at a sports event.  I do notice a bit of blurring in pictures with motion.  With motion, or even worse low light + motion, it can take a couple attempts to get a picture I am fully satisfied with.As for the battery, it lasts quite a while, well over 300 images.  If that is a major selling point for you, just keep in mind batteries for this camera are ~$10; keep a few on hand maybe even a second charger if it is a big issue.  I personally did not want to sacrifice quality, price, or size in order to gain longer battery life.My main gripe with this camera is that it didn't include a USB cable, and it doesn't use the same one my smartphone uses.  I figure if you are going to design the camera to take the less common type of connector you should at least include a cable.All my gripes combined are not enough to dock a star for this camera.  For the niche it is an extremely good camera.  I call it a niche, but the niche is basically doing everything well and on the fly without having to change lenses or tweak numerous settings.  This camera is well rounded and inexpensive, so don't expect it to outperform a DSLR.  That said DSLR cameras are usually larger/heavier, more expensive, require multiple lenses and much setup, and generally require a deeper  understanding of how a camera works.

Reviews.Title: Love Love Love
Reviews.Author: Donna
Reviews.Content: I am a photographer...and will admit that due to the film going away to digital I have not had the love for it that I had when I first got into to....I do still love my Minolta 35mm (although it is put away as no one seems to know how to print from film any more) and I love my Sony digital that I use professionally....that said...this camera has made me fall in love with photography all over again....the first few days I just could not put it down....and now I am anxious to get out and see what I can shoot! Thanks Canon for restoring my love of photography! The camera is also light weight, which is awesome for someone like me who has been dealing with pain issues.

Reviews.Title: Best Camera ever!
Reviews.Author: Alan Berends
Reviews.Content: Zooooooooooooooooooom even past that.  50 power but you better buy a tripod.  Took shots of the Eclipse last night April 14 to 15 and I could zoom it so it OVER-FILLED the screen.  Get a programmed flash, 420EX by Canon, and be ready to take some of the finest pictures possible with a point and shoot.  I did a lot of research before buying this, and this has the best ratings and actually performs up to those ratings.  Just buy it and thank Canon for one of the finest cameras ever.  It would take thousands of dollars in lenses to match this with a reflex camera.  They have abilities that this can't match, but for the price, this is your camera.

Reviews.Title: Great but where's the cable?
Reviews.Author: Biology teacher
Reviews.Content: Great camera, real value! Took it on a trip and was a little amazed at how far the powershot SX line has come since the SX30 that I replaced. It is a much smarter camera -- detecting faces and sunsets and tracking moving objects, figuring out what to focus on, electronic level. And the zoom power is great, all in a light-weight package. The videos also are great. My one complaint is that this model did not come with the cord to connect to the computer (I was able to use the one from the SX30). That was a little mystifying, why they should drop it from the package. So if you buy this, along with the SD card, you will likely want to get a cable.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera
Reviews.Author: R. Phillips
Reviews.Content: 5 stars for value for price factor. Well built, solid. Flash is adequate for family oriented, non-professional work but don't try to shoot a wedding with it professionally ;0)  Has a flash override which I use a lot, many times I need a fill flash in bright sunlight to avoid harsh shadows on a facial portrait (eg at the beach). So-so quality in existing light situations; again, you're not paying top dollar either. It's good for me, but for those who love dark settings/existing light it will be iffy results, sometimes great, sometimes not depending on conditions. Shooting at a full, bright moon on a clear night with stars will give good results, shooting the moon when overcast at night with tree branches will not have a good result. You will totally love the zoom, and the anti-shake feature at extreme zoom is excellent. I shot a wedding recently, and got some great candids. 300 people and I could stand at the far end of the hall and easily frame a head & shoulders on someone at the other end. They didn't know I was photographing them so I got some really nice shots. No blurs from handshake, there was slightly dimmed lighting in the hall for mood. General outdoor has excellent, deep color. On scenics, especially wildlife, you will kiss this camera, trust me. Your finger will never leave the zoom lever. Camera also has wide angle/24mm which is about as wide as you can get without going into fisheye lenses. Good for mountain ranges, etc.Canon has put out another great camera.

Reviews.Title: Keep your SX30IS or SX40IS for night shots
Reviews.Author: Tony Reed
Reviews.Content: I "upgraded" to this camera from the SX30IS. Based on the reviews, I expected better speed and more artistic flexibility. I was wrong.First, the SX50HS's nighttime performance is far below that of the previous SX cameras, due to the so-called "upgrades." First, if you're using a shutter slower than 1 second, the camera takes away any ISO options and locks it on 100- Since I like to take a lot of SFX photos, that limitation sucks.Second, it has a hard time focusing at night- It can't seem to find anything in low-light situations and is constantly searching. The SX30IS is exceptional in this regard but the SX50HS sucks.Finally, the only option for night shooting is a "high speed burst" which combines several photos, similar to HDR. You have no option but a tripod with this and if anything moves in the shot, it's lost.The only remaining options are to toggle back and forth between manual and aperture priority till you find something useable.Zoom- incredible. Flip-out screen- marvelous. Daytime performance exceeds most DSLRs and can be operated with one hand.Quicktime video? WTF were they thinking? That sucks. Nobody uses that crap, Canon, get rid of it.I've had this camera over a month and have a love/hate relationship with it. I loved my previous SX30IS and I'm beginning to regret that I sold it to get the SX50IS.

Reviews.Title: Excellent, I love it.
Reviews.Author: J. Arceo
Reviews.Content: I did a research for about three weeks, I read tons of reviews from experts to consumers. I also went to my local B.Buy to hold and try different cameras, and I just fell in love with the cannon SX50. I'm not a professional photographer, but with this camera I feel like one. The pictures come out great, I'm very impress with the quality of the pictures, there is no need for the built in flash since the camera performs great in low light conditions. I also bought the Replacement NB-10L Battery for Canon PowerShot G15 G16 G1 X SX40 SX50 HS that way I have a back up battery. But the most important feauture of this camera is the 50x zoom, I have taken awsome pictures and videos of the Moon, and the planet Jupiter (and even 3 of Jupiter's moons). I also bought Case Logic DCB-304 Compact System/Hybrid Camera Case and Transcend 16GB Class 10 SDHC Flash Memory Card. You may want to check out this video review from youtube ( [...] ).

Reviews.Title: Perfect camera
Reviews.Author: GREAT case
Reviews.Content: Perfect camera, It takes real good quality pictures, and works very good on long distance. I love it very much

Reviews.Title: Canon Power Shot SX50 HS  Super duper camera!
Reviews.Author: Levimom
Reviews.Content: Excellent camera, be sure to get the 'cheat shee' item to make familiarization easier for the novice.  Taking some great photos and having lots of fun doing it!

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: BTGS
Reviews.Content: The more you use it, the more you are able to do new things. The picture is super clear! The zoom is amazing! It's definitely a great camera for someone who doesn't want to have to learn how to use a some times complicated camera...

Reviews.Title: GREAT CAMERA
Reviews.Author: billyboy "William White"
Reviews.Content: I researched a lot of cameras!! I started off with point and shoots and most of them got  not so good reviews I would love to own a DSLR but the cost is out of my price range ( after lenses and stuff) soooo....this camera fit the bill. I LOVE IT the lens is great for telephoto outdoor applications.Short focal lengths indoors (with the flash) is great.  you can use it in manual mode or go full auto. I got around 200 pics on a battery charge and this was with a lot of playing with the lens focal lengths. if you use the camera in the highest quality  mode you can print really good, to amazingly good pics. the screen is bright and useful most of the time if you like a eyepiece view this one is great you can adjust how much info you see when you are getting ready to shoot. the software that came with it was useless!!... but I didn't try too hard to get it to work, I just used windows pics. I haven't used the movie part (other than to try it out) it seemed fine. If your looking for a transitional camera (between point and shoot and a pro setup) this is a great way to go.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: Pen Name
Reviews.Content: I thought about buying a camera with less zoom, but decided on this one. I think I am happier with this one.And I was told that the megapixels did not matter as much as people often think.  The only time megapixels matter is if you want to blow up a picture.So after all the research I did I feel like I got the perfect camera.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot SX50 HS 12MP Digital Camera with 2.8-Inch LCD (Black)
Reviews.Author: Paul
Reviews.Content: This is a replacement for a prior model. Used primarily as a studio camera it has decent quality suitable for presentation materials. Very solid camera, good features and the swivel screen is great.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: Mark S.
Reviews.Content: This camera is great!  I love it, I definitely need some classes to figure out how to use all of the fun settings, but for now the auto setting works great!!!  Great action shots too!

Reviews.Title: I'm thrilled
Reviews.Author: Nedith V.
